title: 110_hr2399
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007". Congress recognizes the seriousness of alien smuggling as a transnational crime that threatens border integrity, national sovereignty, and security. They commend the efforts of law enforcement agencies like the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice in combating this threat. Alien smuggling is a serious transnational crime that threatens border integrity and security. The law enforcement community, including the United States Coast Guard, Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Department of Justice, must have the necessary tools to address this threat. State and local agencies, medical personnel, social service providers, and the faith community also play important roles in combating smuggling. Existing penalties for alien smuggling are deemed insufficient. Existing penalties for alien smuggling are insufficient to provide appropriate punishment for alien smugglers. Current laws often fail to reach the conduct of alien smugglers, transporters, recruiters, guides, and boat captains. Laws concerning failure to heave to are also inadequate in punishing boat operators and crew engaging in reckless transportation of aliens on the high seas. Extraterritorial jurisdiction is necessary to ensure that smuggling rings can be brought to justice. Alien smuggling rings operate outside the United States and require extraterritorial jurisdiction for prosecution. Smuggling can involve dangerous conditions leading to high risks of injury or death for individuals seeking unauthorized entry into the country. The Department of Homeland Security will check alien smugglers and smuggled individuals against terrorist watchlists at U.S. borders. Additionally, there will be stronger prosecution and punishment for alien smugglers. Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. This includes bringing individuals to the United States without lawful authority and recruiting or encouraging them to enter or reside in the country. The amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act addresses the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, punishing those who bring individuals to the United States in any manner, regardless of official action, and those who recruit, transport, harbor, or conceal them. The amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act punishes individuals who bring aliens to the United States outside designated ports of entry, regardless of official authorization, with fines, imprisonment, or both. The amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act outlines various penalties for different offenses related to bringing aliens to the United States, including fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the specific circumstances of the offense. The amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act specifies penalties for offenses related to bringing aliens to the United States, including fines, imprisonment, or both, based on the intent and circumstances of the offense. Offenses committed for profit or with the intent of the alien committing a serious offense result in harsher penalties, including fines and imprisonment ranging from 3 to 15 years. The penalties for offenses related to bringing aliens to the United States under the amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act include fines, imprisonment, or both, ranging from 3 to 30 years based on the intent and circumstances of the offense. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in serious bodily injury, endangers a person's life, or involves individuals engaged in terrorist activity. The penalties for offenses under the amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act include fines, imprisonment up to 30 years, or both. Harsher penalties apply if the offense involves serious bodily injury, endangers life, or terrorist activity. Offenses involving kidnapping, attempted kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, attempted abuse, attempted murder, can result in fines, imprisonment for any term of years, life, or both. The amended Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act allows for extraterritorial jurisdiction over offenses described in paragraph (1). In prosecutions for certain violations on the high seas, a defense based on necessity cannot be raised unless reported to the Coast Guard promptly. In prosecutions for offenses on the high seas under Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, a defense of necessity cannot be raised without promptly reporting to the Coast Guard. Reporting includes details of the necessity and, if applicable, a rescue operation involving an alien. Bringing aliens into the US without lawful authority is prohibited unless exigent circumstances endanger their lives, in which case reporting to the Coast Guard after delivering the alien to safety is required. In cases of offenses on the high seas under Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, a defense of necessity must be promptly reported to the Coast Guard. This includes reporting details of the necessity and any rescue operations involving an alien. Bringing aliens into the US without lawful authority is prohibited, except in cases where their lives are in danger, in which notifying the Coast Guard after delivering the alien to safety is required. The term 'United States' includes various territories and possessions, and 'lawful authority' refers to permission provided in immigration laws or regulations. The term 'lawful authority' in the United States refers to permission provided in immigration laws or regulations, excluding any authority obtained fraudulently or not approved. SEC. 5. MARITIME LAW ENFORCEMENT. Penalties for violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. If the offense is related to specific crimes, the offender may face a fine or imprisonment up to 10 years. If a violation of section 2237 of title 18, United States Code involves specific crimes such as serious bodily injury, inhumane transportation conditions, death, kidnaping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder, the offender may face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment. In a prosecution for a violation of section 2237 of title 18, United States Code, no defense based on necessity can be raised unless certain conditions are met, including delivering the person to emergency personnel and reporting to the Coast Guard. In a prosecution for a violation of section 2237 of title 18, United States Code, a defense based on necessity requires delivering the person to emergency personnel, reporting to the Coast Guard, and not facilitating the entry of any alien into the US without lawful authority, except in exigent circumstances. The term 'transportation under inhumane conditions' is defined as transporting persons in confined spaces, at excessive speeds, exceeding the rated capacity of the means of transportation, or intentionally grounding a vessel with persons on board. The term 'transportation under inhumane conditions' includes transporting persons in confined spaces, at excessive speeds, exceeding capacity, or intentionally grounding a vessel with persons on board. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO THE SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses and obstruction of boarding. Considerations include enhancements for repeated violations, involvement in commercial organizations, and transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses, including enhancements for repeated violations, involvement in commercial organizations, transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens, and facilitation of terrorist activity. The Commission may use expedited procedures to promulgate the guidelines or amendments. The Sentencing Act of 1987 will be applied as if the authority had not expired.
